Guy Foster, Head of Research at Brewin Dolphin comments: “The prime minister’s negotiating strategy revolves around making the market’s most feared outcome look like his preferred outcome. Hence we are seeing a lot of weakness in the pound. That leaves the pound very cheap but sentiment will remain poor unless one side looks ready to seek a compromise. With the EU expecting parliament to prevent a no deal Brexit there will be reluctance to compromise.

“The Prime Minister’s premiership relies upon building momentum for no deal. That leaves the pound in between an unstoppable force and an immovable object.”

At a glance: All eyes on GBP as key-supports are being penetrated
 In general – Comments from the new UK government increased hard Brexit fears even further, so that GBP
broke internal 76.4 % Fib.-retracements at 1.2172 in Cable and at 0.9109 in EUR/GBP. But with GBP now
being the cheapest currency within G10, the situation remains tricky, as the slightest positive news could
trigger fairly severe short covering. Technically though and given the just mentioned breaks, it can’t be
excluded anymore that former GBP lows from 2016 are now being challenged again. In terms of high beta
FX, we see a bit of a “Make-or-Break” situation given as AUD/USD has for example reached its countertrend
decline target zone between 0.6890 and 0.8841 (int. 76.4 % on 2 scales), from where a recovery looks
possible. But as long as the leading S & P 500 hasn’t cleared weekly triangle resistance at 3033, the setback
risk for the latter and for high beta FX remains high. No news in EUR/USD where the risk of extending the
downside towards 1.1059/26 (Fib.-projections), if not to 1.0864 (76.4 % of the 2017-2018 rally) remains high
as long as 1.1188/1.1213 (pivot/minor 38.2 %) is capping the upside.

BE11:25am

 Intensified hard Brexit fears led to another sell-off in the last 3 days, which has now reached the projected
countertrend decline target zone between 1.2172 and 1.1989/88 (76.4 % of the 2016-2018 rally/1.5 %
tolerance/2017 low) from where we at least expect a temporary bounce to 1.2504/27 (d. trend/minor 38.2 %).
 Ultimately, it now requires a range breakout between 1.1988 and 1.2527 to provide confirming evidence
whether the 2017 low at 1.1491 could potentially be re-tested or whether the long-term countertrend decline
has potentially reached an exhaustion point at 1.2119.

BE11:34am

CNA reported its 1H19 results this morning, alongside a wider strategic review.

· The results table is provided below and our view, post discussion with the company is that EPS guidance for this year is now at ~7p/sh driven by continued weakness in gas prices, nuclear outages, warm weather and the impact of the tariff cap. Full details on the segments are provided in the table below.

· More importantly CNA has also announced a strategic review that includes a re-basing of the 2019 dividend to 5p/sh, confirmation of planned disposals in E&P and nuclear, the retirement of the CEO and further cost efficiencies.

Overall, while much of this content was expected, we don’t think today’s announcements necessarily signal the bottom in the share price. The company still seems happy with consensus EPS for 2020 of ~10p/s. However if we rebase for the nuclear and E&P disposals (where proceeds will be retained to fund efficiencies and meet tougher credit rating requirements) then EPS will likely be 2-.2.5p/sh lower. If we then apply the new dividend cover target of 1.5-2.0x to a revised ~7.5-8.0p/sh of adjusted EPS then it is hard to see much growth in DPS into 2020. We think a yield of ~6% is about right for a challenged business with limited growth opportunities and hence there could still be further downside to the current share price with a 6% yield on a 5.0p/sh dividend implying a valuation in 80-85p/sh range.

Flaneur @Nightingale - asset prices far too high - economy gerrymandered by BoE at expense of social spending - electorate react - Brexit = correction.Cummings knows this and is driving for it. Smart man. He'll produce a new generation of Tory voters like Thatcher did.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Details
· EBIT down 49%, EPS down 63% - see table below which highlights the key movements in the numbers for 1H19. The key drivers in the period were the UK default tariff cap, low UK gas prices, outages at Hunterston B and Dungeness B and warm weather in the period both in the US and UK.

· Expect to meet 2019 financial targets - CNA continues to expect to meet cashflow targets of operating cash flow in the range £1.8-2.0bn and net debt in the range £3.0-3.5bn. Achievement of the cashflow target has been boosted by ~£200m in structural working capital improvements.

· Dividend - rebased to 5p/sh for 2019, with CNA citing pressure on operating cashflow from the UK price cap, higher pension cash requirements following triennial valuation and restructuring costs as key factors. Targeting dividend cover of 1.5-2.0x, whilst the scrip alternative has been cancelled.

· Iain Conn to step down as CEO - CNA announced separately that CEO Iain Conn will step down as CEO and retire from the board next year. Iain Conn will remain with the company until at least the 2020 AGM.

· E&P sale by 2020 - CNA expects to dispose of its interest in Spirit Energy by the end of 2020, via a trade sale, in addition to the already announced intention to dispose of its 20% stake in Nuclear power generation by 2020. Combined we value these business at ~£2.5bn (split ~£850m in nuclear and ~£1.75bn for CNA’s share of Spirit Energy).

· Efficiencies target increased to £1bn 2019-22 - CNA is targeting £1bn of annualised efficiencies over 2019-2022, up £250m versus the previous target.

· Business unit repositioning - Connected Home will be refocused on the UK and Ireland around Home Energy Management, the business will be renamed Centrica Home Solutions. Structural interventions will be made in North America business to improve through cycle returns and reduce returns volatility.

· Net debt - Reported at £3.34bn versus £2.7bn at FY18. This includes £394m impact from adopting IFRS 16 as of 1st January. The triennial pensions review has now been finalised, with the company committing to make additional cash contributions. Contributions will total £223m in 2019, and £175m per annum thereafter until the deficit is cleared. The overall pension liability balance is ~£1.4bn from ~£1.2bn previously.

marktime That BP debt though
BE11:34am

RBC Fundamental View
We continue to see limited future growth prospects in downstream operations of CNA, with the core business shrinking and new business struggling to mature. Furthermore, lower commodity prices, nuclear outages and warm weather have put further pressure on earnings. We do not think today’s announcements signal a reversal in fortunes and we continue to advocate an Underperform stance.

BE11:34am

And UBS.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Key messages at a glance
We set out the H1 numbers in the full table overleaf. In sum: EPS at 2.4p has missed consensus by 20%, driven by North America and by the E&P division which Centrica now intends to divest. Even allowing for a stronger H2, full year EPS could now struggle to reach consensus earnings of 8.2p. Finally: management proposes a dividend cut to 5p, but with no scrip option, meaning this comes quite close to our expected 6p with scrip (but below consensus 7.5p). Reuters also reports CEO Iain Conn will step down.
What were the key negatives?
Many of the negatives have been expected since the Q1 trading statement (weather, switching, outages). New today however was: (1) Connected Home losses extended to £49m (EBIT), with decision to "refocus activity to the UK " (i.e. exit US, international); (2) N. America Business made a loss of £14m due to warm weather and limited gas optimisation; (3) E&P/storage made £148m (consensus: £204m) impacted by "dry hole" costs at Greater Warwick and commodity prices; (4) Pension deficit of £1.4bn, contributions rising from £98m pa (2018) to £223m (2019); and £175m pa thereafter.
Where could there be room for more optimism?
The main positive is that most of the bad news is now out, reducing the risk of further unknown downsides from here. Cashflow guidance is maintained for end year (although after factoring a £100m boost to the working capital target) and for future years (although after extending the cost target by another £250m). The dividend comes with target guidance of 1.5 – 2x "in the medium term", which could imply 2020/21 EPS of 9-10p assuming some growth. BG Services is also gaining accounts again.
Valuation: Positive reaction possible on DPS cut to 5p, but may not hold.
Reaction could be a small positive, despite the miss. The main point is that it could have been worse, and with a cash dividend of 5p confirmed, investors now have some motivation to wait around and see what happens next. Yet still we would not get too excited: once again the update highlights the unpredictability of Centrica's business mix, and at current levels (after factoring in the proposed dividend cut) the shares would trade on a 2019E DY of 5.5% (compare Enel 5.2%; Fortum 5.2%; Engie 5.5%).

marktime The retail energy price cap has clobbered big suppliers and still the minnows have gone bust owing a fortune in climate change levies
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Having prepped the market for a dividend cut in February, the actual
reduction remarkably still came in lower than expectations at 5ps (we were
at 7p, but the market was at 6p). Dividend growth from 2020 will link to
EPS and operating cash flow (previously operating cash flow only), but we
were disappointed to see coverage expectations set very conservatively
greater than 1.5x (although the scrip has been turned off). 1H EPS came in 36% below us at 2.4p/s, driven by a raft of misses (see table below), with FY expectations declining 1p/sh as a result. CNA will exit E&P in 2020 via a
trade sale of Spirit Energy, although proceeds will be used to shore up the
balance sheet and prop up the pension fund with no hint of capital
management. Pension deficit repair (an additional £75m/a) is inline with
our expectations, but the balance sheet overall requires strengthening due
to reduced diversification post asset sales. The key positive is the
announcement than the CEO will step down in next year, making way for
a fresh perspective on strategy, but we feel this will be broadly balanced by the litany of negatives strewn through the release.

BE11:38am

We initiated on Centrica in May with an Underweight rating and a 85p price target – ‘It can still get worse’ (17 May 2019). Our thesis was that we feared that their retail division is reaching a point where :i) continued customer losses will offset cost cutting efficiency measures, ii) Ofgem’s price cap is setting the margin at too low a level to cover the financial commitments to sourcing molecules and electrons and iii) no material improvement in the financial performance of the connected home.

We see the CMD as ‘evolutionary’ rather than ‘revolutionary’ with increased cost-cutting and clarity on upstream options.

Here's Alphavalue on Hammerson

BE11:46am

We have downgraded Hammerson again after we being caught up by the drop in the share price. We cannot come back to a fundamental positive opinion as long as there is such a pace in devaluation. Brexit remains another issue, obviously. Just look at the increasing level of CVAs despite the healthy consumer spending in the UK. Up to now, the NAV has been driven more by the yield decompression (or anticipations), rather than revenue itself. Having disposed of one of its best and biggest assets in France (Italie Deux / Paris), and waiting for some other disposals in Spain (2020, AV's assumption), the exposure to the UK should gradually increase.

Irish HF guy yes Intu tomorrow, will be interesting. My projection is £800m approx loss!
BE11:47am

Due to the current 57% discount vs. the released H1 19 NNNAV, it is a little harder to find some downside potential. However, as Brexit doesn't look to be integrated in Hammerson's current operational figures (rents), we've decided to increase the discount to peers from 40% to 50%. The impact of our DCF is important as we now consider the hypothesis of a declining long-term EBITDA.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And Credit Suisse.

BE11:48am

It’s no surprise that operational metrics have turned more negative in the
UK, but the metrics across the board are weak. Positives include a further
very strong performance from outlets and completing the majority of the
group’s FY19 disposal target.
■ LFL NRI growth of -0.1% was in-line with our expectation, although UK
shopping centres at -6.8% and Ireland at -7.4% (mainly due to HoF CVA at
Dundrum) were even weaker than expected, whereas Outlets were
stronger at +11.1%. A deterioration in performance included UK shopping
centre leasing at -8% vs. last passing and -4% vs ERV (+1% and +5% in
FY18) whilst over-renting of retail parks expanded to -7.6% (from -1.1% in
FY18) despite -6.3% ERV growth as H1 was against weak comps. In
addition, 25% of UK shopping centre lettings were on a temporary basis
(14% in FY18) at 26% below prior passing and 55% below Dec-18 ERV. A
little more positive was an improvement in footfall which turned positive
across all segments and a slowdown in the retail sales decline to -2.0%
from -2.9% for UK shopping centres. EPRA EPS of 14.0p was slightly
ahead of our estimate of 13.6p.
■ EPRA NAV decline of -7% to 685p was weaker than our 706p estimate with
material further valuation write-downs in the UK (-9.1% shopping centre, -
10.9% retail parks) and extending to negative movements in Ireland (-3.2%)
and France (-3.9%, driven by the mark down in Italie Deux ahead of sale).
Including Outlets, the portfolio value fell -4.4% which was in-line with FY18
with a 20bps expansion in equivalent yield to 5.5%.
■ The £423m disposal of 75% of Italie Deux in Paris was a welcome boost
towards the £500m disposal target for FY19. The headline price of a 4.1%
net initial yield relates to the main centre and the overall price is 8% below
Dec book value. We note that pricing is complicated by the extension which
is part-way through and 41% pre-let; the completion of this is delayed which
is in favour of the buyer. We last visited the centre a couple of years ago
and view it as dominant in a strong urban location supported by the local
population including students, although the look-and-feel was jaded with low
ceiling heights and a tenant mix in need of revitalizing. Strategically, we like
Hammerson selling in France where it does not have critical mass.
■ LTV on a proportionally consolidated basis increased 3ppts to 46%, but
would fall by about the same amount pro forma on completing the Italie
Deux disposal. Net debt to EBITDA of 10.2x increased to marginally above
management’s 10x target prior to completion of the disposal.

Tom Dalgleish @Irish, customers are becoming more wary
BE11:49am

marktime Talking of M&A targets I imagine overseas prospectors looking at the UKs discounted property sector
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Latest data shows transaction activity in UK real estate investment markets down 44% in 2Q. Deal volumes and numbers are down, even in the strongest subsectors; historically these trends have correlated well with capital growth trajectory. Overall – further weakening in momentum in 2Q: For the UK as a whole, investment transaction volumes have fallen (1): 2Q volumes fell 44% year-on-year, with last 12-month volumes down 20% (-18% excluding retail). Quarterly volume growth was negative across all major subsectors. Though quarterly data can be revised, deal numbers are also down (-16% in the last 12 months, -26% in 2Q year on year). Yields are flat to slightly up, except in industrial/logistics where deal activity remains elevated (4).On London offices: London office volumes have held up relatively well in recent years (10), but fell 41% in 2Q year-on-year. Deal numbers remain close to trough levels in a longer-term context, not helpful for capital growth rates, as we show (6), and have only been lower once since 2000 (in 1Q09; see 16). Transaction yields, have moved out modestly in recent periods, but are broadly stable vs. 2016 levels (22).On UK retail/shopping centres: Volumes and deal numbers in shopping centres and retail parks remain close to record lows, while yield data are patchy (and the quality spectrum wide); but in the last 12 months we've seen shopping centre volumes close to the trough levels last seen in the global financial crisis.On UK industrial: Prior year volumes are flattered by some very large transactions (11), but this quarter's activity has continued to moderate lower, down 32% in the last 12 months (17). Deal numbers were down 13% in the quarter, 10% last 12 months. Transaction yields have fallen c.20-30bps over the last 12 months. Recapping where we stand on UK property. Many UK REITs continue to position themselves defensively for falling markets via lower gearing; and use surplus cash for shareholder returns or for refinancing expensive debt, to drive NAV and/or earnings per share, even in a flattish market. We continue to forecast a weak capital growth outlook overall; but note that many share prices are now at close to historically cheap levels, on both an NAV valuation and an income yield basis, despite low leverage. Many UK shares screen as 'optically cheap', based on historical measures (see 34-37), but we see still see better returns elsewhere in the listed European sector, namely in logistics, German residential and in Spain. Our only Overweight in the UK is Segro.

Berenberg. Sector thing.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

After three weeks spent inside one of the UK’s best-performing fashion retailers
learning from industry experts about the practicalities of retail, we share our key
findings in this note. Our learnings come from both the business in which we were
based and from insights shared by industry experts about their experiences at other
retailers across the sector. We discuss five key takeaways below and provide some
readacross to stocks under our coverage. In this note, we downgrade ASOS from Buy to
Hold after its latest profit warning.
● Lesson 1 – people and culture: While perhaps obvious, the importance and impact
people can make within a retail business is underestimated, in our view. While we
often look for evidence of automation to minimise risk, due to its forward-looking
nature, fashion is inherently a people-driven business. However, even the strongest
hires cannot make an impact without the right organisational culture. These aspects
can be very difficult to assess externally, but going forward, we will be scrutinising
these key areas more closely.

Excel Developer Any BP grey today?
BE11:57am

● Lesson 2 – product: As detailed in our March 2017 sector report, You reap what you
sew, as product life cycles have accelerated and competition across the sector has
increased, picking fashion product winners has become more difficult. While the
Inditex-style data-driven business model has its advantages, we believe investors have
become overly focused on speed to market rather than an overall assessment of a
retailers’ design, buying and merchandising capabilities. For example, while most
European brands can replenish from Turkey on 6-8 week lead times, often the highest
rates of sale often come in the first 4-6 weeks following launch, meaning that a
replenishment strategy does not work. A successful strategy relies on strong designers
and buying teams not only picking the winners, but backing them with sufficient order
volumes. A retailer hedging its bets across a broad range of product can be as fatal as
designing poor product in the first place. It is surprising, then, that retailers rarely, if
ever, discuss their differentiation here.
● Lesson 3 – infrastructure: There are significant discrepancies between retailers across
the sector with regards to the quality of infrastructure that supports key functions,
inventory management, buying and merchandising, and ecommerce. This can make
what appear to be simple tasks to outsiders more complicated in practice for many
legacy retailers. While having strong teams can offset systems weakness in the short
term, ultimately it can prevent or delay improvements to the proposition and increases
operational risk. However, such systems are often interlinked, making upgrades
complicated, risky and expensive.

BE11:57am

● Lesson 4 – marketing: We believe the structural change in marketing dynamics (or
customer acquisition) caused by the internet has been just as significant for the sector
as the change in distribution channels. Declining footfall has blunted the effectiveness
of a retailer’s store estate as a marketing tool, forcing legacy retailers to find new
(incremental) ways to acquire customers. However, a retailer’s marketing strategy
must clearly be linked to its product availability: there is little point in pushing
consumers towards a certain product if it quickly sells out. Timing the marketing to
match availability of product, when shipments can easily be brought forward or
delayed, can be harder than it looks. It is especially difficult when the marketing may
show a range of items (ie the whole outfit) which can arrive at different times. Further
marketing complexity stems from a brand’s relationships with its distribution partners,
which may now ultimately compete with the brand for customer acquisition online.

cheeckychappy @BE - apparently Boris Johnson's new director of comms dressed up as a chicken and chased around Dave Cameron during the 2010 election for the Mirror. Is this news?
11:57 am
BE11:58am

● Lesson 5 – product margin: We believe most retailers constantly track product margin
across every product line alongside sales performance, and the outcome is far more
controlled than investors perhaps appreciate. In terms of currency impact or input cost
inflation, hedging clearly gives time for buying teams to react to FX moves, be it through
supplier negotiations (or change of supplier), or product changes. Such negotiations are
easier to process for a growing retailer, which makes it an attractive customer to suppliers.
Where a retailer has lost control of the product margin, it is therefore a significant indication
of turmoil within the business in our view.

BE11:58am

● Recommendation changes – ASOS down to Hold: We downgrade ASOS from Buy to Hold.
While we continue to believe its product and marketing strategy are attractive, it is difficult
to forecast when the recent infrastructure upgrades will bear fruit given recent execution
issues. The latter has also exposed people and culture issues in the organisation. We believe
ASOS has already acknowledged these issues and is targeting improvement in these areas,
but this may take some time.

BE12:00pm

Here's Barclays to sum.

BE12:00pm

We expect a positive reaction to BP’s release this morning with earnings 14% ahead of company compiled consensus and a strong performance in underlying cashflow, which we calculate as $6.8bn, and implying a $53/bl cash break-even in the quarter. A good performance upstream was particularly encouraging reflecting both strong gas trading and a lower exploration expense, although the downstream was clearly hit by maintenance. Moving forward gearing is now set to start to fall from this point and BP’s statement highlighted that the group remains committed to fully offset the impact of the scrip dilution since 3Q 2017 by the end of 2019. On our numbers this implies BP needs to repurchase an additional 393m shares – essentially $2.5bn, giving an indication of the underlying FCF generative ability of the company. We continue to see BP’s shares as offering significant value and we rate the stock Overweight with a 700p/sh price target.

BE12:01pm

Or in bullet points:

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Earnings

· Dividend per share of 10.25 cent is flat q/q.

· Adjusted net income of $2,811m was 14% ahead of the company compiled consensus, and 30% higher than our forecast

· Adjusted EBIT of $5,160m was 5% ahead of consensus driven by a stronger than expected Upstream and Rosneft performance, partly offset by weaker than expected downstream.

· A lower than expected tax rate helped the larger beat at the net income line.

· Upstream production of 2,640kboe/d was 1% ahead of our forecast, up 7% y/y.

· We estimate upstream net income per barrel of $9.2/boe, up $0.5/boe y/y and compares to the $6/bl fall in Brent oil price.

Cashflow and net debt

· Reported cashflow from operations of $6.8bn was up 8% y/y, with a $1.5bn release of working capital and $1.4bn of post-tax Macondo costs.

· Excluding working capital and Macondo charge, we estimate underlying cash flow of $6.8bn, up 21% y/y.

· With cash capex of $3.7bn and dividends of $1.9bn, there was a positive FCF post capex and dividends of $1.2bn.

· As such, we calculate organic cash breakeven pre Macondo of $53/bl, down $21/bl y/y but up $8/bl q/q.

· Net debt of $46.5bn was up 3% q/q with gearing (net debt to capital) of 31% up 1pp q/q.

Outlook

· Expect share buyback to fully offset scrip by end of 2019.

· Re-iterated 2019 guidance for organic capex to be $15-17bn and the target to divest over $10bn by 2020 with gearing moving towards 10-20%.

· Expect 3Q upstream production to be lower q/q due to maintenance.

· Expect lower turnaround and industry refining margin in 3Q.

marktime Miles ...
BE12:01pm

And RBC.

BE12:02pm

Our key takeaways from this set of results are:

1. Net income $2.8bn vs consensus $2.46bn. Group EBIT beat consensus by 5%, primarily driven by the upstream, while the effective tax rate in the quarter was 34%, below BP’s full year guidance at 40%.

2. We calculate underlying cash generation at $6.8bn, vs RBCe $7.5bn. Adjusting for all the various elements including Macondo & working capital, cash flow fell short of our expectations in the quarter, despite the earnings beat. Gearing was also slightly ahead of our estimate at 35.5% (NB BP’s gearing figure excludes lease liabilities from IFRS16).

3. 2H19 cash and gearing momentum should improve. BP’s financial framework should look much improved as we move into 2H19 given Macondo and BHP payments were both first half weighted. We expect to see gearing start to creep lower as we move through the year.

RBC Fundamental View – Outperform, PT 615p

We remain constructive on BP for its medium-term growth profile and improving cash flow framework. This growing profile should lead to improving returns to shareholders via dividend increases and buybacks, once the balance sheet is de-levered to levels in line with the sector.

BE12:08pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
Q2 LfL sales growth was flat, missing consensus at +1.9%. H1 EBIT was down -10bps to 23.6%, above consensus at 23.3%. H1 EPS beat by +4% (+1% from EBIT, +2% from finance costs and +1% from non-controlling interests/other); details overleaf. However, 2019 guidance for LfL sales growth was lowered to 2-3%. We expect the stock to be muted: despite the EPS beat (and a weak GBP implying upside to consensus EPS forecasts, all else unchanged), the miss on LfL growth and the guidance cut remind investors once again that RB is not out of the woods yet.

BE12:08pm

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
(1) Q2 LfL for Health was -1%, missing consensus at +1.3%. Within Health, OTC returned to growth with +1% LfL (in-line), but IFCN (flat vs cons +2%) and Other Health (-3% vs cons. +0.4%) both missed expectations. RB said it saw some share declines in the China infant formula market and reported a "relatively flat" Q2. (2) RB has set out a "Health Action Plan" where it intends to step up investments in China IFCN to increase distribution, launch a new Mucinex 'Night Shift' range in OTC, and work on the re-focus of Scholl and a strong innovation pipeline for Durex in 2020. (3) HyHo Q2 LfL was +3%, in-line with expectations at +2.9%. (4) H1 EBIT margin was down -10bps, with a -20bps decline in GM and a +10bps increase in brand & marketing spend partly offset by a -20bps lower SG&A. (5) FCF was down -3% y/y.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Q: Has the company's guidance/outlook changed?
Yes: RB has lowered its 2019 guidance for like-for-like sales growth to 2-3% (previously 3-4%) but it continues to see a flat EBIT margin. Consensus expectations before today's announcement were +2.8% organic sales, 26.6% EBIT margin (flat y/y) and EPS up +1% to 345p.

BE12:08pm

Valuation: Valuation discount reflects uncertainty on LT margins; Neutral
At 18.4x 20E P/E, RB trades at a -15% discount to its EU Staples peers. We think this multiple is fair considering the risk on the sustainability of RB's long-term EBIT margin and the uncertainty on how quickly its top-line growth will accelerate again.

BE12:09pm

Flat like for like sales for the quarter fell short of consensus (+1.9%). This was all about the Health business (-1% like for like in the quarter), with IFCN (0%, China slowdown) and the rest of health (-3%, Scholl, Dettol and Durex) coming up short of expectations. The OTC business and Hygiene and Home performed in line with expectations at +1% and +3% respectively.
Guidance for the full year has been reduced to 2-3% like for like revenue growth from 3-4% reflecting this, albeit the company expects ‘improving trends for H2’. While it’s true that the comp for Q3 is undemanding, on current form it seems to us to owe more to hope than expectation.

This hope seems to be based on Reckitt Benckiser’s intention to increase ‘investment in BEI [Brand Equity Investment] and medical marketing to improve growth’. This should be music to our ears, but given that there is no change to Reckitt Benckiser’s full year operating margin expectations our enthusiasm is limited. It’s true that 1H’s operating margin was 40bps ahead of consensus, but we’d be surprised if this is enough to turn around Reckitt Benckiser’s revenue performance in a sustainable way.

This is all less interesting than it would normally be, with new CEO Laxman Narasimhan due to take control in a just over a month. We think he’s been presented with a great opportunity to revive Reckitt’s sales growth but this will require significant investment. Nothing in these results has changed our mind.

BE12:12pm

Post the call: A details-heavy call which brought reassurance on the shape of H219 despite the
disappointment in H119 which led to today’s trimming of the 2019 guidance. On the top line building blocks we
note: 1) a £70m sales recovery in IFCN, 2) heavy innovation (Enfinitas, Mucinex, Dettol, Durex, HyHo), 3) signs of improvement in Dettol as price increases are rolled back. On the margin front, we note the positive JPMe 30bps benefit from lower variable pay for FY19E which – amongst other things – contribute to the makeup of flat margin in FY19 despite the topline warning in Health. This along with the profit recovery in IFCN in Q319 makes it improbable, in our view, that the margin outlook will be lowered at Q3 stage as the market feared this morning. Besides, as the debate rages in the market on a) a margin reset by the new CEO and b) whether HyHo may not be spun/sold off , we note the key priority from CEO-designate Laxman Narasimhan: a laser focus on delivering shareholder value through 1) sustainable outperformance in Health and 2) driving RB2.0. To us, this continues to open the door to transforming the business towards a standalone, focused, consumer health company while the repeated management mantra of ‘margin being structurally sustainable’ should keep the bears re-basing stories at bay though we would welcome extra investments if this were to accelerate top line. As we look into a recovery in Health and HyHo optionality, we would continue to take opportunities of share price weakness to build into the equity story.

BE12:16pm

BP reported a resilient set of 2Q19 results this morning (July 30th), with RC operating profit at US$5,160 mn, +5% above company-compiled consensus (+8% qoq) and RC adjusted net income at US$2,811 mn, +14% above company-compiled consensus (+19% qoq). Across divisions, the earnings performance was driven by a stronger than anticipated upstream, with E&P RC operating profit +10% above company-compiled consensus, in line with our expectations (GSe US$ 2,796mn), supported by a solid production in the quarter, at 2,625 kboepd (+6% yoy, flat qoq) on the back of ramp-up of major projects offsetting ongoing seasonal turnaround and maintenance activities. Downstream, R&M performance was relatively weak this quarter, -13% below company-compiled consensus on the back of planned turnarounds ahead of IMO2020, whilst performance in Rosneft was resilient, +10% above consensus and +13% qoq.
Operating cash flow (pre-Macondo, pre-OWC) was this quarter at US$6.75 bn with capex at US$3.70 bn, leading to US$3.05 bn of free cash flow (pre-OWC, pre financial charges). The company has stated that looking ahead, it expects 3Q19 production to be lower than 2Q19 reflecting seasonal turnaround and maintenance activities whilst on the downstream the company expects lower level of turnaround activity.
Valuation and risks
We are Buy rated (on CL) on BP with 12-month price targets of 810p and US$62.0 (ADR), based on 8x EV/DACF applied to 2020E cash flow.

1. Upside to dividend in 2H: "We are more than well underpinned on the cash flow targets we laid out to 2021. I think the Board will definitely want to come back to dividend", management said.2. Buyback to accelerate in 2H too: "We've also got somewhere close to $1.8 billion of buybacks to come in the second half of this year that will offset the scrip since the third quarter of 2017."3. Confident in $4-5bn disposals in 2019: "We're pretty confident in terms of the disposal program. It's just taking longer; there is more private equity involved in some of those low 48 assets [...] We're still seeing a pretty good suites of buyers for the assets that we have for-sale."4. Gearing to fall ~600bp by end-2020: "We expect gearing to trend down through the second half of the year, back into the 27% range [from 31% at the end of 2Q19]. [After that, ] we continue to expect gearing to move towards the middle of our targeted range of 20% to 30% through 2020."5. Expansion into low-carbon businesses accelerating: "I also want to talk about the focus we're giving to the energy transition and our low carbon agenda. All of these businesses are central to our growth agenda into the next decade and beyond and core to the integrated global energy business we are continuing to shape."6. Gulf of Mexico payments to fall sharply: "Pretty much all the BEL claims [ie Business Economic Loss claims] are done [...] We said [GoM payments would be] just around $2 billion for this year, but we're pretty much [done given the payments in 1H19]".7. Slow ramp-up in the Permian, dependent on pipeline capacity: "In terms of Permian, it will be slow progress through this year, as we make sure that the evacuation routes are available. IMO 2020 to support refining margins by year-end: "Refining margins are expected to see support with the implementation of IMO 2020, which should also contribute to increase widening of light to heavy crude differentials".9. Careful about 'Transfer of Rights' area in Brazil: "The 'Transfer of Rights' [area in Brazil] looks very expensive. We're just going to remain very disciplined within our capital framework. We haven't made a decision yet [but] we're going to be really, really careful before we leap into that."

the half way pointof itsfive-year strategy planBP appears to be well on track. 2019 was neverset tobe a spectacular year given heavy maintenance and disposals, but both earnings and cashflow have so far proved surprisingly resilient. Gearing does remain at the top end of the peer group but as we move into 2H with the absence of Macondo and BHP cash payments and the potentialfor divestment proceeds, absolute free cash generation should be materially positive. In turn we see this leading to an acceleration of cash returns to shareholders. BP remains committed to fully offsettingthe impact of the dilution from the scrip dividend since 3Q 2017 by the end of 2019. On our numbers this implies BP needs to repurchaseclose to an additional 300m shares, essentially $2bn within the next six months –an annual buyback rate of $4bn. We see this as giving an indication of the company’s ability to generate underlying free cash flow. Our own analysis continues to show that BP’s 2021 strategy plan which envisages upstream pre-tax FCFof $14-15bn and $9-10bn on the same metric in the downstream is wellon track and we share BP’s confidence inits financial framework and its ability to deliver additional cash returns. We rate the shares Overweightwith a 700p/sh price targe

BE12:18pm

And Caz.

BE12:19pm

Fundamentally, BP continues to deliver on our OW thesis led through strong execution of high margin barrel projects and a differentiated downstream business. With BHP and the last of the major Macondo payments behind it ($1.7bn and $1.4bn in 2Q respectively), underlying gearing has peaked this quarter at 31% ND/CE and is expected to trend lower from 2H led by continued delivery and ramp up of upstream projects including Constellation and Culzean. Elevated gearing in 2019 is well flagged and we believe BP’s long-term upstream growth pipeline offers the sector’s most attractive mix of capex headroom and returns which will allow to company to further compress a 6.4% yield. BP sits in the middle of the sector range on cash return (buyback and dividend as a percentage of market cap) and we look for further clarity on its divestment outlook ($1.5bn in 1H vs. target to deliver greater than $10bn over the next two years) given this remains an important pre-requisite to increasing shareholder distributions.
